content: The Act titled "No More Land Act" limits the use of funds from the Land and Water Conservation Fund. The Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965 is amended to change "acquisition and development" to "maintenance" in various sections. The Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965 is amended to specify areas of national forests and wildlife refuges for outdoor recreation and endangered species protection. The head of each covered landholding agency must reduce backlogged maintenance by 20% within 5 fiscal years of the enactment of the Act, and continue to reduce maintenance backlog in subsequent 5-year periods. The Act mandates covered landholding agencies to reduce backlogged maintenance by 20% within 5 fiscal years and continue reducing backlog in subsequent 5-year periods. It also addresses any outstanding reduction in backlogged maintenance and additional maintenance that arose after the enactment date. SEC. 4. REPORTS ON REDUCTION OF BACKLOGGED MAINTENANCE. The head of each covered landholding agency must publish and submit reports to Congress documenting progress in reducing backlogged maintenance on agency lands. Reports must include the dollar value of reduction achieved in a 5-year period, whether the required reduction was achieved, and any shortfall in reduction amount. The head of a covered landholding agency must publish and submit reports to Congress detailing construction, deferred maintenance, and regular maintenance projects needed to reduce backlogged maintenance. The reports must also include a plan for carrying out these projects over the next 5 fiscal years, with the first report due within 30 days after the end of the first 5-fiscal-year period following the enactment of the Act. Subsequent reports must also be published and submitted. The covered landholding agency must submit reports to Congress detailing backlogged maintenance on federal lands, with a final report due once all maintenance is completed. The final report must prioritize lands based on program success and describe a regular maintenance system. The covered landholding agency must submit reports to Congress detailing backlogged maintenance on federal lands, with a final report prioritizing lands based on program success and including a system of regular maintenance and a list of capital improvement projects. The covered landholding agency must prioritize federal lands based on their importance to program success and submit a report to Congress within 4 years of this Act. Definitions are also provided in the legislation. The Act defines "backlogged maintenance" as the total dollar value of incomplete regular maintenance, deferred maintenance, and capital improvements on lands under covered landholding agencies. The backlogged maintenance is set at $600,000,000 for lands under the Bureau of Land Management and $2,300,000,000 for lands under the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service, and National Park Service have allocated $314 million, $11.5 billion, and $314 million respectively for maintenance. Covered landholding agencies include the Bureau of Land Management, United States Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service, and National Park Service. Maintenance refers to the upkeep of real property.
